title: Actress Angela Lansbury, Who Excelled in Stage, Film and TV Roles; Discovered as a teen during World War II, she became known for lauded performances in 'Mame,' 'Sweeney Todd,' 'The Manchurian Candidate' and 'Murder, She Wrote'
text:
Ms. Lansbury's television credits included a role in the 1965 CBS series 'Trials of O'Brien.'

The actress with director Gower Champion in 1970. Ms. Lansbury and Mr. Champion collaborated on the musical 'Prettybelle,' which closed in Boston in 1971.

Ms. Lansbury in rehearsals for 'Gypsy' in London in 1973. The next year, she won a Tony for playing Mama Rose in a revival of the production.

Ms. Lansbury with Roddy McDowall in a scene from 'Bedknobs and Broomsticks.'

The actress as Mrs. Lovett and George Hearn as Sweeney Todd in a 1982 showing of the Broadway musical 'Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.' Ms. Lansbury originated the role, for which she won the Tony in 1979.

Ms. Lansbury celebrated the 100th episode of 'Murder, She Wrote' in 1989. The show ran for 12 seasons and she was nominated for 12 Emmy Awards—one for each season.

The actress endeared herself to younger moviegoers as the voice of Mrs. Potts, a maternal teapot in the 1991 Disney film 'Beauty and the Beast.'

Ms. Lansbury accepted an honorary Oscar from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Hollywood in 2013.

Ms. Lansbury in the Noël Coward play 'Blithe Spirit' in 2014. Her performance earned her an Olivier Award for best actress in a supporting role.

A commemorative brick at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa. Ms. Lansbury was the first inductee of the playhouse's hall of fame.

Ms. Lansbury at the Gielgud Theatre in London in 2014. Discovered as a teen during World War II, she continued working well into her senior years.

Actress Angela Lansbury, Who Excelled in Stage, Film and TV Roles
